holdings.text: The present case relates to a case pending immediately before 30 June 1966 before a Special Judge within the meaning of section 5(1)(a) Criminal Law Amending Act 1966.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Charge-sheet filed Jan 1966, adjourned to July 1966; proceedings possible pre-30 June per Asgarali precedent: pending if not concluded and court can act.

holdings.text: The words 'charged with and tried for an offence under the principal Act' in section 5(1)(a) CLA 1966 mean accusations and allegations against the person, not that charges have been framed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between cl(a) (with civilians, no framing reqd) and cl(b) (military alone, framing reqd); CrPC ss251A-254 allow discharge pre-framing if groundless.

holdings.text: Section 125 Army Act is not discriminatory or violative of Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in the case of Ram Sarup v. The Union of India considered the question whether section 125 of the Army Act could be said

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Ram Sarup precedent: discretion guided by Act policy; Magistrate/Govt can review; not unguided.

holdings.text: No court martial proceedings are pending against the appellants; they are to be tried by the Special Judge.

anchor.surface_text: It is also in evidence that no court martial proceeding is pending and the appellants are to be Tried by the Special Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: OC cancelled notice; no further military action; evidence shows no pending CM.

holdings.text: The Special Judge has jurisdiction to try and dispose of the case.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge therefore has jurisdiction to try and dispose of the case. It is a case pending before 30 June, 1966 and under Act 22 of 1966 it is to be tried and disposed of by the Magistrate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: procedures complied, OC prefers criminal court, CLA 1966 applies, no conflict.

precedents.citation: Ram Sarup v. The Union of India 1964 5 S.C.R 931

anchor.surface_text: This Court in the case of Ram Sarup v. The Union of India 1 companysidered the question whether section 125 of the Army Act companyld be said to be discriminatory and violative of Article 14 of the Constitution. In that case Ram Sarup who was subject to the Army Act was tried by the General Court Martial found guilty and sentenced to death.

precedents.case_name: Ram Sarup v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 125 of Army Act not discriminatory under Article 14; discretion guided by Act's policy; Magistrate can question; Central Government final decider on forum; if no effectual military proceedings, report to State Govt; final choice of forum with Central Government
precedents.cited_holding: there is sufficient material in the Act which indicates policy which is to a guide for exercising discretion and it is expected that the discretion is exercised in accordance with it. The Magistrate companyld question it and the Government in case of difference of opinion between the views of the Magistrate and the Army authorities decide the matter finally.

precedents.citation: Som Datt Datta v. Union of India Ors. 1969 2 S.C.R. 177

anchor.surface_text: This Court in the recent decision in Som Datt Datta v. Union of India Ors.  1  companysidered the effect of rule 3 of the Rules framed under section 549 of the Code of Criminal Pro- cedur The petitioner in that case made an application under Article 32 for a writ of certiorari for quashing the proceedings before the Court-Martial whereby he was found guilty of charges under sections 304 and 149 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to 6 years rigorous imprisonment.

precedents.case_name: Som Datt Datta v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Rule 3 applicable after police investigation and charge-sheet submission; section 125 Army Act decision for Court Martial; sections 125 and 126 provide machinery to resolve jurisdiction conflict
precedents.cited_holding: These two sections of the Army Act provide a satisfactory machinery to resolve the companyflict of jurisdiction having regard to the exigencies of the situation in particular case.

precedents.citation: Joginder Singh v. State of Himachal Pradesh Criminal Appeal No.34 of 1969 decided on 30-11-1970

anchor.surface_text: This Court in the recent unreported decision in Joginder Singh v. State of Himachal Pradesh 1  companysidered the question as to whether the trial and companyviction by the Assistant Sessions Judge in respect of an offence, under section 376 of the Indian Penal Code violated provisions of the Army Act read with criminal Courts and Court Martial  Adjustment of Jurisdiction  Rules, 1952.

precedents.case_name: Joginder Singh v State of Himachal Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Absence of notice under rule 4 not fatal if military authority hands over accused to civil authorities indicating decision for trial by criminal court; no exclusion of criminal court jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: the absence of a numberice under rule 4 was number fatal in the facts and circumstances of the case because the companypetent military authority knowing the nature of the offence released the accused from military custody and handed him over to the civil authorities

precedents.citation: Major E. Barsay v. State of Bombay 1962 2 S.C.R. 195

anchor.surface_text: This Court referred to the earlier decision of this Court in Major E. Barsay v. State of Bombay  2  for the proposition that there was numberexclusion of Jurisdiction of the ordinary criminal companyrts in respect of offences which are also triable by Court Martian.

precedents.case_name: Major E G Barsay v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: No exclusion of jurisdiction of ordinary criminal courts in respect of offences which are also triable by Court Martial

precedents.citation: Asgarali Nazarali Singaporawalla v. The State of Bombay 1966 S.C.R. 678

anchor.surface_text: The word pending 9 came up for companysideration before this Court in Asgarali Nazarali Singaporawalla v. The State of Bombay 1 . Criminal Law Amendment Act. 1952 provided for the trial of all offences under section 161, 165 or 165-A of the Indian Penal Code or sub-section  2 . of section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 exclusively by Special Judges and directed the transfer of all such trial pending on the date of the, companying into force of the Act to Special Judges.

precedents.case_name: Asgarali Nazarali Singaporawalla v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Meaning of 'pending' case: matter not concluded where court having cognizance can still make order on the issue; test is whether proceedings can be taken
precedents.cited_holding: The word pending will ordinarily mean- that the matter is number companycluded and  1  1966 S.C.R. 678 8 94 the companyrt which has companynizance of it can make an order on the matter in issue. The test is whether any proceedings can be taken in the cause before the companyrt or tribunal where it is said to be pending.
